title: 109_hr3894
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hurricane Katrina Emergency Housing Act of 2005". Waivers are provided for the Section 8 Voucher Program. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive requirements for assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 for individuals or families affected by Hurricane Katrina. The waiver of eligibility requirements under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 may be granted for individuals or families affected by Hurricane Rita if their residence became uninhabitable or inaccessible due to the disaster, and rental assistance was provided on their behalf. The curr_chunk discusses various provisions related to rent assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937, including waivers, eligibility, income verification, lease requirements, housing unit inspections, portability restrictions, and lease terminations. The curr_chunk discusses a model lease allowing lease terminations for tenants ineligible for assistance, including those who would not meet screening criteria. It also mentions regulations for limited English proficiency access to federally funded programs. The termination period specified is 12 months from the enactment of the Act. The Act allows for waivers under this section for a 6-month period from the date of enactment, unless the Secretary determines they are no longer needed. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can directly administer voucher programs if a public housing agency is unable to do so due to Hurricane Katrina or Rita. Waivers are also allowed for project-based Section 8 to help affected families. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive certain requirements for project-based assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 for individuals or families meeting specific criteria. Waivers include tenant rent contributions, income verification, and other related provisions. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive requirements for project-based assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937, including lease term, initial inspection, and approval for lease terminations based on eligibility or screening criteria. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive requirements for project-based assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937, including lease approval and screening. The specified period for waivers is initially 12 months from the enactment of the Act, but can be reduced to 6 months if the Secretary determines that waivers are no longer necessary. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF PROJECT-BASED SECTION 8 HOUSING ASSISTANCE PAYMENTS CONTRACTS FOR DAMAGED OR DESTROYED HOUSING UNITS. Project-based housing assistance payments contracts for units damaged by Hurricane Katrina or Rita will not expire due to damage. The contract will end three months after units are habitable. SEC. 6. REPORT ON INVENTORY OF AVAILABILITY OF FACILITIES AND PROPERTIES FOR HOUSING USE. The Secretary of various agencies, including HUD and Defense, must compile an inventory of federal facilities and properties that can be used for emergency housing within 20 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, along with other agency heads, must compile an inventory of federal facilities and properties suitable for emergency housing within 30 days of the Act's enactment. This inventory must be submitted to Congress for review. The inventory compiled by the Secretary includes all inventories submitted to the Secretary. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will identify States with emergency housing plans for disasters, describe the plans, and assess their effectiveness.
